name: National_Measured_Conductivity_Data_NWIS
description:
The information displayed is based on measured specific conductivity (SC) data retrieved from the USGS NWIS. NWIS data are based upon consistent, documented sample collection and measurement techniques, as well as consistent data reporting. Data was downloaded for river and stream sampling sites between January 1, 1984 and April 20, 2018. Data collected prior to 1984 were excluded because analytical methods used by USGS prior to that date are less reliable. The downloaded dataset includes more than 1 million water chemistry measurements, collected at 65,698 NWIS sampling stations in the continental U.S. (covering all states and most ecoregions). 

After retrieval, the data were then processed and screened to ensure that only the most appropriate data would be retained. Null records (missing) and numerical values ≤ 0 were removed. Remark codes from NWIS were identified and reviewed, one sample was noted as an estimated value. The numbers of SC measurements available at individual sampling sites varies (mean = 15 measurements; mode = 1, i.e., many sites were only sampled once). Data sampling sites that a high number of SC measurements were averaged on a daily basis. At these sites, outliers can exist due to the large number of measurements, and lead to increased mean and median SC values. The screening process is outlined below:

  • Values that suggested uncertainty in the measurement were excluded (e.g., measurements with undefined codes).
  • Only the following water body types were considered: estuaries, lakes, reservoirs, and streams/rivers.
  • The time period for the data was restricted to 1980 through 2018.
  • SC measurements were averaged daily. This reduced the influence of high frequency sampling at certain sites.
  • Sampling sites located at ditches, canals (e.g., irrigation) and bays were excluded.

The initial download of national water quality data from NWIS totaled 4,982,862 measurements from 959,946 samples, collected at 5,901 sites.  Of these, a total of 553,700 and 1,043,953 conductivity samples were analyzed in the field or laboratory, respectively. The final dataset (post screening) consisted of 784,936 conductivity samples at 19,562 unique sampling sites. 

The data that resulted from processing and screening data retrieved has some limitations, for example:

  • The databases do not reflect a random sampling of U.S. surface waters. They contain datasets with a diversity of sampling design and thus data may be biased towards stations and water bodies with known water quality impairments.
  • Spatial bias may also exist due to unequal sampling efforts in different parts of the U.S. For instance, some states are disproportionately represented, even when the relative surface water area likely to be contained within each state is considered.

Generally, the resulting database contains more data from sampling sites in larger river and stream systems, and areas subjected to proportionately greater human influence compared with random statistical sampling. Users should verify the data from the original sources before drawing site specific conclusions.

documentInfo.subject: The "National Measured Conductivity Data - NWIS" view consists of a tile service derived from United States Geological Survey (USGS) National Water Information System (NWIS) data .
documentInfo.keywords: NWIS, Conductivity, Freshwater, Hydrology, Ion, NHD, Aquatic Life, EPA, Geospatial
